Why is the United States, including the police dept. in Ferguson, still such a racist nation? Mainly it is because we have not worked to address the problem in our educational system and stamp it out. When a police officer arrives with racist attitudes or latent hostility toward minorities, an effort could be made to either change the officer's outlook or move him or her out of the job. Instead, the leadership and city officials ignored massive violations of Constitutional rights while, apparently, paying no attention to racism as a problem. This is not an uncommon, nor is it limited to Ferguson by any means.

American police officers receive much less training than those in Europe and other wealthy nations. That's part of the overarching difficulty. If a police commander orders officers to violate Constitutional rights, the officer has to know what those rights are to be able to resist. It is clear that one short session of training is not enough, that police officers need recurrent training as well.

Take away ALL of the Tasers from the Ferguson police force. They are an invitation to the use of excessive force because they allow an officer to "take control" of a situation with less risk of death or serious injury to the perpetrator. They are a fascist's dream weapon. They don't belong on American streets.

It is clear we need a much stronger, wider and sustained effort to defeat racism. We had the great Civil Rights movement, but it was not enough.

Rob: There is a difference between scientific fraud, scientific error, and doing the best possible that later turns out to be not true. The "stand out scientist" who "proves" climate change is false doesn't exist.

There are scientists who claim there is no climate change, and there are scientific arguments about that. The argument has been going on for at least 20-30 years now and the weight of evidence and reasoning is strongly in favor of the existence of human-caused global warming. There are some scientists who still argue against that, and their arguments, when they are scientific, are taken seriously and discussed. They have not yet turned out to be strong enough to convince many scientists; if anything, it's been the opposite. That's how science is supposed to work.

There are also "scientists" (often without relevant expertise) and pure amateurs who are sure they understand things better than 98% of the experts. They don't need to be debated scientifically because most or all their arguments have been demolished already; they just haven't been keeping informed. Unfortunately, they can convince many people, especially when they have the backing of deep pockets, e.g., from petroleum interests.
Thinking like that is why America is in so much trouble.

I loved this piece!  Thank you, Mr Widmer, you captured for me something of the existential nature of Mr Lincoln.  I always felt that Lincoln was a man that spent a great deal of time staring into the abyss, starring until he might have said: I was skinned and purged of all ego and need for flattery, until all that remained was a wounded understanding feeling to express what was needed and knew had to be done.  Little wonder then that those at his speeches came away scratching their heads and needing time to  put the wonder of his words among the annals of the best speeches ever given. No, I doubt we'll see the likes of Mr Lincoln again, a lanky fellow from the backwoods that wrote his own words between constant emergencies, and revised and reduced them to their briefest essence.
